summary: This research investigates the impact of customer incivility on employee service performance through an integrative framework based on self-determination theory. The study reveals that the negative effects of customer incivility on employee performance, mediated by intrinsic motivation, are influenced by employees' core self-evaluations. Specifically, employees with higher core self-evaluations are less negatively affected by customer incivility compared to those with lower evaluations, indicating that individual differences in self-perception play a crucial role in how employees respond to challenging customer interactions.
